title-group.article-title: A study of the secondary piston motion arising from changes in the piston skirt profile using a simplified piston skirt model

article-meta.aff: Department of Engineering Science, Oxford University, Oxford, UK

author-notes.corresp: PD McFadden, Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, UK. Email: peter.mcfadden@jesus.ox.ac.uk

abstract.p: An existing model of the interface between a parallel-sided piston skirt and the cylinder wall in an internal combustion engine is extended to allow the modelling of barrelling of the piston skirt. The effects of the skirt profile on the secondary motion of the piston and on the distribution of pressure in the lubricant film are examined. It is shown that piston secondary motion, and in particular rotation of the piston about the gudgeon pin, which might contribute to wear of the cylinder, can be reduced by appropriate positioning of the maximum diameter of the piston skirt in relation to the gudgeon pin and the centre of mass of the piston.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The effects of barrelling of the piston on piston skirt loads and friction losses in an internal combustion engine have been investigated by Wong et al.1 and by Mansouri and Wong,2 but both used models which assumed an exactly constant crankshaft speed, and were therefore unable to explore what effect short-term variations in crankshaft speed during the engine cycle might have on the secondary motion of the piston.

Briaris3 developed an engine model which differed from previously published work in that it was a fully dynamic model, where the crank speed was not assumed constant, but was determined by the gas pressure applied to the piston crown, the inertias and stiffnesses of the engine components and the magnitude of the brake load applied to the output shaft. A schematic view of the single-cylinder version of the model developed by Briaris and later reported by McFadden and Turnbull4 is shown in Figure 1. For a nominal crankshaft speed of 4000 r/min, it was found that the instantaneous crankshaft speed during the engine cycle varied between 3997 and 4009 r/min, confirming the importance of this approach. Briaris included a detailed and comprehensive model of the piston skirt and showed that it was possible for the piston to travel the full length of the bore without making contact with the walls of the cylinder. This was achieved when the gap between the piston skirt and the bore was both fully and partially filled with oil. It was also shown that barrelling of the piston skirt allowed the piston to undergo more secondary motion, although a gap between the piston skirt and the bore was still maintained. Figure 1.
Schematic of crank and slider geometry: (a) side elevation and (b) front elevation in direction A.

Following the work of Briaris,3 McFadden and Turnbull5 showed that changes in the way the journal bearings in the engine were modelled had little effect on the magnitude of the loads being carried by the journal bearings, but that changes in the way the piston skirt was modelled did have significant effects both on the secondary motion of the piston and on the magnitude of the loads being carried by the skirt. In contrast to the earlier works of Wong et al.1 and Mansouri and Wong,2 which were based on the surprising premise that the piston skirt underwent significant elastic deformation while the oil film played no part, the model used by McFadden and Turnbull5 assumed a rigid piston, the motion of which was entirely controlled by the squeeze film forces in the lubricant between the piston skirt and the cylinder wall. The model of the piston skirt/cylinder wall interface used was very simple compared to that developed by Briaris, but it did predict values of interface pressures and secondary movement that came very close to those predicted by the much more complicated model. The success of the simple model, therefore, justified this article, in which the simple, parallel-sided piston skirt model is modified to include barrelling, and used to predict the effects of changing the barrel's parameters on the secondary motion of the piston.
For a full review of the relevant literature and for details of the model, the reader is referred to McFadden and Turnbull4,5 respectively.

sec.title: General description
sec.p: The mathematical model is as described by McFadden and Turnbull5 and it comprises one cylinder of a multi-cylinder engine model. The bore and stroke are 80 mm, and all the elements of the engine are assumed to be rigid, with the mass and inertia concentrated at the centre of mass of each of the elements. All the journal bearings are assumed to carry the load hydrodynamically, along with the piston skirt. The hydrodynamic model is a simple one in that only the squeeze film term is retained, because Cameron6 has stated that in internal combustion engines the hydrodynamic term can be ignored. The gas load on the piston has a peak pressure of 2.7 MPa, the brake load 21.3 N m and the nominal speed of the crankshaft 4000 r/min. The physical dimensions of the model are taken from an existing 1.6 L petrol engine. The equations of motion are solved using the Kutta–Merson method, the advantage of which is its ability to maintain a specified accuracy.

sec.title: The barrelled piston
sec.p:
The piston skirt is divided into 32 identical ‘pads’, each occupying an angle of ±45° either side of the centre, and capable of carrying a load due to elastic contact with the wall of the cylinder and by a squeeze film pressure generated by the relative sideways velocity of the piston and the bore. In order to investigate the effect of barrelling of the piston skirt, a profiling function has been produced which modifies the shape of the piston skirt. As shown in Figure 2, the three parameters which control the barrelling are RT and RB, the amount the piston radius has been reduced at the top and bottom of the skirt, respectively, (both set to 30 µm unless otherwise stated) and L/D, which is the point on the piston skirt where no reduction has been made, and hence where the maximum diameter occurs. Figure 2.
Definition of barrelling terms.

A simple polynomial of the form y = a + bx + cx2 has been used to shape the skirt, and when applying the boundary conditions, the following equations were evaluated ▵Rn={RT(1-2DLyn+(DL)2yn2)Yn<L/DRB(D-1)2(1-2DLyn+(DL)2yn2)Yn≥L/D

Figure 3 shows the way the profile can be changed by varying L/D and/or varying RB. The barrel profiles that will be investigated are D = 2, D = 4 and D = 4/3, which have their maximum diameter near the centre, top and bottom of the skirt, respectively. A fourth profile having no barrelling (i.e. with parallel sides) will be used as the basic shape with which the others can be compared. Figure 3.
Reduction of piston nominal radius for different skirt profiles.

Real pistons may have more complex profiles, derived from experience and theory, and such profiles could be readily incorporated in the model using different functions to describe the variations in radius. The profiles used here are assumed to include the effects of thermal expansion.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: To enable direct comparisons with the work of Briaris,3 the parameters of the model used to generate the following results are the same as those used by Briaris, including the subroutine which calculates the gas pressure above the piston crown, as described in McFadden and Turnbull.5 The piston height is 70 mm, with the centre of mass located 40 mm from the top and the gudgeon pin 45 mm from the top. There is no gudgeon pin offset. The initial radial clearance between the piston skirt and the cylinder wall was 20 µm, and barrelling increased this to 50 µm both at the top and bottom of the piston skirt.

sec.title: Piston motion
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the effect of moving the point of maximum diameter of the piston skirt on the lateral translation of the centre of mass of the piston. It is seen that the parallel-sided piston has the least lateral translation of the centre of mass (i.e. displacement in the x-direction as indicated in Figure 1(b)), whereas moving the maximum diameter close to the top of the piston skirt (i.e. D = 4) produces the greatest amount of translation. Conversely, moving the maximum diameter close to the bottom of the piston skirt (i.e. D = 4/3) produces a translation of the piston which is nearer to that produced by the parallel skirt. Wong et al.1 suggested that this latter piston shape is the one most favoured by engine manufacturers. Figure 4.
Lateral translation of centre of mass of piston for different skirt profiles.

Figure 5 shows the rotation of the piston about its centre of mass. It can be clearly seen from Figures 4 and 5 that positioning the maximum diameter near to the bottom of the skirt appears to be the most advantageous, as it allows the piston to be barrelled with the minimum increase in both translation and rotation of the piston. Recalling that the gudgeon pin is located at 45 mm from the top of the piston, below the mid-height, it becomes clear that a barrelled piston with maximum diameter at mid-height (D = 2) or above (e.g. D = 4) will experience larger rotations because the increased vertical separation of the gudgeon pin and the maximum diameter will produce greater moments for a given horizontal component of the thrust of the connecting rod. Locating the maximum diameter close to the gudgeon pin (e.g. D = 4/3 for the engine configuration described here) will minimise the rotation of the piston, as shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Rotation of piston about its centre of mass for different skirt profiles.

Briaris3 investigated a piston with the same amount of barrelling as was used to generate Figures 4 and 5 (i.e. RT = RB = 30 µm) and with the maximum diameter in the centre of the piston skirt (i.e. D = 2). The movements of the piston predicted were very close to those shown in Figures 4 and 5.

Figure 6 shows the rotation of the piston about its centre of mass for D = 4/3 with different amounts of piston radius reduction at the bottom of the piston, the original reduction being 30 µm. It can be clearly seen that reducing the amount of radius reduction near to the bottom of the skirt appears to be advantageous in that it reduces the amount of rotation of the piston without any significant change in the translation of the piston. Figure 6.
Rotation of piston about its centre of mass for different values of RB.

sec.title: Losses due to friction
sec.p:
As the model predicted no contact between the piston skirt and the cylinder wall, it was felt that an investigation of the losses due to viscous friction and the resistance from the piston rings would be worthwhile. Figure 7 shows these friction forces, which are mainly due to viscous friction, the effect of the piston ring friction only being obvious in the small step change in force at the top and bottom dead centre where the direction of travel of the piston reverses, as indicated in Figure 7 for 360°. It is interesting to note that the reduction in friction loss does not appear to depend on the shape of the barrelling, but depends mainly on the actual amount of material removed from the piston diameter. Figure 7.
Friction force between piston skirt and cylinder wall for different skirt profiles.

sec.title: Pressure distribution – parallel-sided piston
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the distribution of pressure, for a complete engine cycle, for the parallel-sided piston. The contours on the right-hand side of Figure 8 show the pressures on the right-hand side (i.e. the thrust side) of the piston as viewed in Figure 1(b), and similarly those on the left-hand side are for the left-hand side of the piston. Contour lines are drawn at intervals of 0.05 MPa for this and all subsequent plots. Figure 8.
Piston pad pressures for parallel-sided piston.

Figure 8 shows that the maximum pressure of 0.51 MPa occurs at a crank angle of 585°, which is close to the maximum pressure predicted by Briaris, although in his case the pressure was not constant around the circumference of the piston, while here it is assumed constant for ±45° either side of the centre. However, the method of calculating the pressure in the oil between the two surfaces used here has the advantage of simplicity, and because of this, the pressure profile of the lubricating oil for a complete engine cycle can easily be calculated and the recorded results are not limited to a particular crank angle. It is worth noting that a similar calculation has been made for the four-cylinder model developed by McFadden and Turnbull,5 and although the distribution of pressure is the same as the single-cylinder model, the maximum pressure was 0.36 MPa.

The small peaks observed in Figure 8 near the top of the piston can be solely explained in terms of the angular velocity of the piston rotation about the gudgeon pin as deduced from Figure 5. At approximately 45°, Figure 5 shows the angular velocity of the piston has a large negative value, corresponding to a clockwise rotation in Figure 1(b), causing the top-right corner of the piston to move towards the right-hand side of the cylinder, thus producing a small pressure peak in Figure 8 at the top of the piston for this angle. At approximately 220°, Figure 5 shows that the angular velocity has a maximum negative value, giving rise to a similar but larger pressure peak in Figure 8 at the corresponding angle. Figure 5 also shows that the angular velocity of the piston has large positive values, corresponding to an anticlockwise rotation in Figure 1(b), at approximately 480° and 560°, moving the top-left corner of the piston towards the left-hand side of the cylinder and so producing the small peaks at the top of the piston at these angles in Figure 8. It is interesting to note that it is the angular velocity of the piston rotation deduced from Figure 5, not the translation shown in Figure 4, which determines the pressure peaks at the top of the piston, because the lateral velocities at the top of the piston due to rotation exceed the lateral velocities of the gudgeon pin due to translation.

sec.title: Forces acting on the piston
sec.p:
The major peaks in the pressure distribution represented in Figure 8 further down the side of the piston can be qualitatively explained in terms of the ‘inertia force’ acting on the piston, equal to the mass of the piston multiplied by its acceleration but acting in the opposite sense to the acceleration, the gas pressure on the piston crown, the force in the connecting rod and the sideways force between the piston skirt and the cylinder. At this part of the cycle, the inertia effects of the connecting rod can be ignored because its linear and angular accelerations are relatively small. Viscous friction forces can also be ignored, given the small magnitudes shown in Figure 7. In the following explanation and in Figure 9, it will be assumed for simplicity that the piston reaches its maximum velocity when the crank is horizontal, at angles 90°, 270°, 450° and 630°. In fact, for the crank and connecting rod lengths modelled here, the maximum piston velocity occurs when the crank is approximately 12° above the horizontal, at 102°, 258°, 462° and 618°. Figure 9.
Forces acting on the piston throughout the cycle. G: gas, I: inertia, C: connecting rod and N: normal.

At a crank angle of 0°, the beginning of the exhaust stroke, the piston is at bottom dead centre and has maximum upwards acceleration, corresponding to a maximum downwards inertia force I, as illustrated in Figure 9(a). The gas force is negligible because the cylinder pressure is only a little above ambient. As a result, the force C in the connecting rod acts vertically upwards, but there is no lateral force between the piston and the cylinder wall. At a crank angle of 45°, as shown in Figure 9(b), the gas force remains negligible and the piston acceleration is smaller so the inertia force has decreased, thus the vertical component of the force in the connecting rod has decreased. However, the connecting rod is now at an angle, and the horizontal component of its thrust on the piston must be countered by a normal thrust force N between the piston and the left-hand side of the cylinder wall, producing the pressure peak seen in the left-hand contours of Figure 8 between 0° and 90°. At a crank angle of 90° (actually 102°, as previously explained), the piston has maximum upwards velocity but its acceleration is zero, and the gas force remains small, so the force in the connecting rod is small as shown in Figure 9(c), and there is no significant sideways thrust on the cylinder wall, giving zero pressure on the piston pads, as shown in Figure 8. For a crank angle of 135°, as shown in Figure 9(d), the piston is being decelerated, resulting in a tension in the connecting rod which is reacted by a horizontal thrust on the piston from the right-hand cylinder wall, producing the pressure peak seen on the right-hand side of Figure 8. Note that in the top half of the stroke, the piston accelerations and hence the inertia forces are larger than in the lower half of the stroke, due to the geometry of the crank and connecting rod. At a crank angle of 180°, the piston is at top dead centre, as shown in Figure 9(e), and the sideways force is zero at bottom dead centre.

During the intake stroke, when the crank angle is 225°, the piston is accelerating downwards, but the cylinder pressure has fallen below ambient, producing an upwards gas force G on the piston which causes an increased tension in the connecting rod, as shown in Figure 9(f), and thus a greater sideways thrust than at 45°, as indicated by the increased number of contour lines on the left-hand side in Figure 8. At a crank angle of 270° (actually 258°, as previously explained), the piston has maximum downwards velocity but its acceleration is zero. However, the upwards gas force G in Figure 9(g) produces a small sideways thrust on the left-hand side of the cylinder. This is confirmed by the left-hand contours of Figure 8 at 270°. Recall that there is no such sideways thrust at 90°. At 315°, Figure 9(h) shows the upwards gas force on the piston countering the downwards inertia force as the piston decelerates, producing a small resultant compressive force in the connecting rod and hence no significant sideways thrust, as observed for the lower pads in Figure 8. At 360° in Figure 9(i), the sideways thrust is zero, as explained for 0°, the beginning of the exhaust stroke.

At a crank angle of 405°, during the first part of the compression stroke, the cylinder pressure is still below ambient according to the trace used by Briaris3 and McFadden and Turnbull,4 so the gas force on the piston is in the upward direction as in Figure 9(j), reducing the compressive force in the connecting rod and hence producing a resultant peak pressure on the left-hand side of the cylinder in Figure 8, which is less than that for 45°, the corresponding position in the exhaust stroke. At 450°, shown in Figure 9(k), the gas pressure has increased to approximately ambient and the piston has zero acceleration, thus there is no sideways thrust. In the second half of the compression stroke, the gas pressure continues to rise, producing a downwards force on the piston, as shown in Figure 9(l), which helps to decelerate the piston, thus reducing the force in the connecting rod and keeping the thrust on the right-hand side of the cylinder lower than at 135°, the corresponding position in the exhaust stroke.

At 540°, the piston is at top dead centre and there is no sideways thrust, as shown in Figure 9(m). During the first part of the expansion stroke, shown in Figure 9(n), the large downwards gas force easily exceeds the upwards inertia force causing a thrust on the right-hand side of the cylinder, producing the peak pressure seen on the right-hand side of Figure 8. At 630°, the inertia force is zero, as shown in Figure 9(o), and the remaining gas pressure continues to hold the piston against the right-hand side of the cylinder, a behaviour which is not seen elsewhere in the cycle. At 675°, in the second half of the expansion stroke, the gas force decreases but the increasing inertia forces holds the piston against the right-hand side, as shown in Figure 9(p).

Armed with the understanding of the forces acting on the piston afforded by Figure 9, the lateral translation and rotation of the piston shown in Figures 4 to 6 can be examined further. It is important to note here that it is not the lateral acceleration of the piston that is related to the normal force, but the lateral velocity, because the pressure in the lubricant film is proportional to the rate of change of the thickness of the film. Thus, it is clear that the normal force is responsible for the ripples on the traces in Figure 4, because the gradient of the trace, representing the velocity of translation, closely matches the magnitude and direction of the normal force in Figure 9. At 0°, 180°, 360°, 540° and 720°, when the piston is at top or bottom dead centre and the inertia force is entirely reacted by the connecting rod with no normal force between the piston and the cylinder, the lateral velocity of the piston shown in Figure 4 is zero. At 45°, 135°, 225°, 315°, 405° and 495°, where the horizontal component of the force in the connecting rod produces a large normal force, the magnitude of the lateral velocity of the piston in Figure 4 reaches a local maximum. Indeed, the largest negative velocity occurs near 225°, where Figure 9(f) shows the inertia force and gas force combine to produce a large normal force on the left-hand side of the piston, and the largest positive velocity occurs a little before 585°, where Figure 9(n) suggests the very large gas force will overcome the inertia force to give a large normal force on the right-hand side of the piston. If further confirmation of the validity of this approach were required, close examination of Figure 4 shows that there is a small negative velocity at 270°, arising from the small normal force on the left-hand side of the piston caused by the small upwards gas force during induction.

The rotation of the piston shown in Figure 5 closely follows the lateral translation shown in Figure 4, because the moment on the piston about its centre of mass is dependent on the couple produced by the normal force and the horizontal component of the force in the connecting rod. Again, it is not the angular acceleration of the piston that is related to the normal force, but the angular velocity, because the pressure in the lubricant film is determined by the rate of change of thickness of the film. Reducing the diameter of the bottom of the piston skirt, as explored in Figure 6, reduces the pressure in the lubricant film in the lower part of the skirt, thus raising the line of action of the normal force further above the gudgeon pin and increasing the moment on the piston, and hence its angular velocity.

Figure 4 shows that barrelling of the piston skirt increases the amount of lateral translation. This will occur because the squeeze film pressure is inversely proportional to the third power of the film thickness, and barrelling therefore decreases the effective film damping coefficient, so that greater lateral velocities must be achieved before the required normal force is produced. For the engine configuration modelled here, with the gudgeon pin below the mid-height of the piston, rotation of the piston also becomes important. For example, with D = 4, the maximum diameter of the piston occurs near the top, so the resultant normal force will be above the mid-height, giving rise to a larger moment on the piston and therefore greater angular velocity of the piston. Thus, at 45°, Figure 9(b) shows the connecting rod pushing the piston towards the left-hand side of the cylinder, as confirmed by the negative slope of the trace in Figure 4 at 45°, and because the gudgeon pin is below the maximum diameter of the piston for D = 4, there will be a negative, or clockwise, moment applied to the piston, resulting in the negative angular velocity shown in Figure 5 at this angle. However, if the maximum diameter of the piston occurs lower, and hence nearer to the gudgeon pin, the moment produced will be smaller, and so therefore will be the translation and rotation, as shown in Figures 4 and 5 for D = 4/3.

sec.title: Pressure distribution – barrelled piston
sec.p:
Figure 10 shows the distribution of pressure for the case when D = 2, when piston has been barrelled by an amount of 30 µm at the top and bottom of the piston, with the maximum diameter being equidistant from the top and bottom of the piston. It can be seen that, although the basic distribution of the pressure peaks is similar, the main peaks have moved up the piston near to but still a little below the mid-height where the diameter is greatest, and the magnitudes have significantly increased, reaching 0.87 MPa during the expansion stroke. The distribution and magnitude of pressure compare well with those predicted by Briaris.3 Note that the small pressure peaks near to the top of the piston generated by the piston rotation have decreased, even though Figure 5 indicates that the angular velocities of the piston have significantly increased. Figure 10.
Piston pad pressures for barrel piston, D = 2.

Figure 11 shows the distribution of pressure for the case where D = 4, for which the maximum diameter is close to the top of the piston skirt, as shown in Figure 3. Although there is a general similarity between Figures 8 and 11, the peak pressures have increased, reaching a maximum of 0.74 MPa during the expansion stroke, and have moved up the piston skirt, to approximately mid-height or a little above, but not as far as the position of the maximum diameter. Pressures generated near the top of the piston are higher than those for the parallel-sided piston throughout the entire cycle, because of the increased piston angular velocities evident in Figure 5. Figure 11.
Piston pad pressures for barrel piston, D = 4.

Figure 12 shows the distribution of pressure for the case where D = 4/3, for which the maximum diameter is close to the bottom of the piston skirt, as shown in Figure 3. Although there is a similarity between Figures 8 and 12, the pressure is now concentrated near or just a little above the maximum diameter, with no peaks occurring near the top of the piston, due to the much smaller angular velocities indicated in Figure 5. The peak pressure is 0.71 MPa, during the expansion stroke. Figure 12.
Piston pad pressures for barrel piston, D = 4/3.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results presented here demonstrate amply the capabilities of the simple piston skirt/cylinder wall model, which is able to produce estimates of the piston rotation and lateral translation, and the distribution of pressure in the lubricant film, throughout the entire engine cycle for any desired skirt profile. While the simplified model cannot deliver the same accuracy as a comprehensive finite element model, it can be used as a tool to explore qualitatively the likely effects of changes to clearances, skirt profile, position of gudgeon pin, position of centre of mass of the piston, piston mass and moment of inertia, connecting rod mass and moment of inertia, combustion pressure profile and engine speed, which if necessary can be refined later using more sophisticated but much slower models, or by experimental measurement.

Using the model, it has been shown that the piston skirt profile significantly affects the lateral translation of the piston and the rotation of the piston about the gudgeon pin. Positioning the maximum piston diameter at a similar height to the gudgeon pin and centre of mass of the piston tends to reduce the moment about the gudgeon pin produced by the normal force between the piston and the cylinder wall, which in turn reduces the rotation of the piston and thus the development of pressure peaks at the top of the piston skirt, as indicated in Figure 12. A large vertical separation between the maximum piston diameter and the gudgeon pin produces larger rotations of the piston, giving rise to unwanted pressure peaks near the top of the piston, as shown in Figure 11. Different combinations of the positions of the maximum piston diameter, gudgeon pin and centre of mass of the piston could be easily explored using the model.

The simple model has also enabled a qualitative explanation to be proposed for the calculated variations in pressure distribution throughout the cycle, entirely in terms of the gas, inertia and normal forces acting on the piston, as illustrated in Figure 9. The effects of lubricant friction and connecting rod dynamics are secondary. It is interesting to note that the gas force appears to play a noticeable role during the induction stroke, when the pressure is below ambient, even extending into the start of the compression stroke until the pressure finally rises above ambient. During the later stages of compression and the expansion stroke, the high gas pressure dominates, holding the piston against the thrust side of the cylinder. However, at part-throttle settings, when the induction pressure falls well below ambient and the combustion pressure is only small, the changed gas forces may significantly affect the pressure distribution in the lubricant. At low speeds, the gas forces will tend to dominate over the inertia forces, but at high speeds, the inertia forces will dominate, except perhaps during the expansion stroke. The influence of different gas pressure profiles and engine speeds could all be easily and quickly explored using the simplified model presented here.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An existing model of the interface between a parallel-sided piston skirt and the cylinder wall in an internal combustion engine has been extended to allow the modelling of barrelling of the piston skirt. The effects of the skirt profile on the piston secondary motion, that is, the lateral translation and rotation of the piston about its centre of mass, and on the distribution of pressure in the lubricant film, have been examined. It has been shown that the piston secondary motion, and in particular the rotation of the piston, which causes the top of the piston to move towards the cylinder wall and thus might contribute to wear of the cylinder, can be reduced by appropriate positioning of the maximum diameter of the piston skirt in relation to the gudgeon pin and the centre of mass of the piston. A qualitative explanation has been provided for the distribution of pressure in the lubricant between the piston skirt and the cylinder wall throughout the complete engine cycle, in terms of the gas, inertia and normal reaction forces acting on the piston. The simplicity of the model ensures that computation times are small, thus making the model suitable for the examination of the effects on the piston motion and lubrication of a wide range of operating conditions.
